facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 413 and 414 of 1958 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 413, and 414 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeals from the order dated April 27, 1955, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Revisions Nos. 81-D of 1953 and 96-D of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the order dated April 27, 1955, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Revisions Nos. 81-D of 1953 and 96-D of 1953 respectively.

facts.text: The appeals were heard on April 21, 22, 23, 24, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: 1959 April 21, 22, 23, 24.-C. K. Daphtary Solicitor General for India, Ram Behari Lal,
1959. May 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR J.-These two appeals

facts.text: Two suits filed against owners of motor cars for recovery of damages suffered by plaintiffs as result of negligent driving.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals arise out of two suits and have been heard together. The suits had been filed against owners of motor cars for recovery of damages suffered by the plaintiffs as a result of the negligent driving of the cars.

facts.text: Owners of the cars were insured against third party risks.

anchor.surface_text: The owners of the cars were insured against third party risks and the insurers were subsequently added as defendants to the suits under the provisions of sub-s.  2  of s. 96 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939.

facts.text: Insurers added as defendants under sub-s. 2 of s. 96 of Motor Vehicles Act, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: and the insurers were subsequently added as defendants to the suits under the provisions of sub-s.  2  of s. 96 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939.

facts.text: Insurers filed written statements taking defences other than those mentioned in sub-s. 2 of s. 96.

anchor.surface_text: On being added as defendants, the insurers filed written statements taking defences other than those mentioned in that sub-section.

facts.text: Plaintiffs contended that written statements should be taken off the records as insurers could defend only on grounds in sub-s. 2.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs companytended that the written statements should be taken off the records as the insurers companyld defend the action only on the grounds mentioned in the sub-section and on numberothers.

facts.text: In one suit, trial court held insurer could take only defences specified in sub-s. 2; in the other, insurers not confined to those defences.

anchor.surface_text: In one of the suits it was held that the insurer companyld take only the defences specified in that sub-section and in the other suit the view taken was that the insurers were number companyfined to those defences.

facts.text: Punjab High Court held insurers could defend only on grounds in sub-s. 2.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the insurers companyld defend the actions only on the grounds mentioned in the subsection and on numberothers.
in respect of private cars, which the vehicles with which these appeals are companycerned were,

facts.text: Policies effected were in terms of the Act and certificate of insurance mentioned in s. 96 duly issued.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated that the policies that were effected in these cases were in terms of the Act and the certificate of insurance mentioned in s. 96 had been duly issued.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that insurer added under s.96(2) entitled to defend only on grounds enumerated in sub-s.2.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore think that sub-s.  2  clearly provides that an insurer made a defendant to the action is number entitled to take any defence which is number specified in it.

facts.text: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 makes insurance against third party risk compulsory under s.94.

anchor.surface_text: Section 94 of the Act makes insurance against third party risk companypulsory.

facts.text: Revision petition pending in High Court between same parties on whether insurer can defend in name of insured.

anchor.surface_text: Apparently there is a revision petition pending in the High Court between the same parties in which that question awaits determination.

facts.text: Court disallowed argument on insurer defending in name of insured.

anchor.surface_text: The Court disallowed this branch of the argument .
and the insurers were subsequently added as defendants to the suits under the provisions of sub-s.  2  of s. 96 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939.

issues.text: Did the insurer have a right to be joined as a party, apart from the statute ?

anchor.surface_text: Subba Rao, J.-Did the insurer have a right to be joined as a party, apart from the statute ? Could he be joined under Order 1, Rule 10, of the Code of Civil Procedure ? I am not basing my case on Order 1, Rule to of the Code of Civil Procedure.

issues.text: the real question before the court is whether sub-s. 2 limits the right to defend on the grounds stated in that sub-section

anchor.surface_text: Das, J.-Is it correct that the statute gives the insurer a right to be joined as a party which he did not have previously ? If so, the right cannot be extended beyond what the statute gives. [...] but the real question before the court is whether sub-s. 2 limits the right to defend on the grounds stated in that sub-section.

issues.text: How can the insurer be allowed to defend in the name of the insured?

anchor.surface_text: Sarkar, J.-How can that be done ? How can the -,insurer be allowed to defend in the name of the insured? How is the record to be kept ? There is no provision under which it can be done, not even under s. 1 5 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

issues.text: The question is whether the defences available to an insurer added as a party under s. 96 2 are only those mentioned there.

anchor.surface_text: Hence these appeals by the insurers. The question is whether the defences available to an insurer added as a party under s. 96 2  are only those mentioned there. A few of the provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act have to be referred to.

issues.text: whether the word manner in sub-s. 6 refers to the procedure or to the procedure and the grounds of defence

anchor.surface_text: As to sub-s.  6  the learned Solicitor-General contended that the proper reading of it was that an insurer could not avoid his liability except by way of a defence upon being made a party to the action under sub-s.  2 . He contended that the word manner in sub-s.  6  did not refer to the defences specified in sub-s.  2  but only meant, by way of defending the suit the right to do which is given by sub-s.  2 .

arguments.claim: The purpose of sub-s. 2 of S. 96 is to state those grounds based on the policy of insurance on which the insurer may rely for his defence.

anchor.surface_text: 1959 April 21, 22, 23, 24.-C. K. Daphtary Solicitor General for India, Ram Behari Lal, D. K. Kapur and Sardar Bahadur, for the appellants. The question in the present appeals turn around S. 96 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939. The purpose of sub-s.  2  of S. 96 is to state those grounds based on the policy of insurance on which the insurer may rely for his defence.

arguments.court_reasoning: Language of sub-s. 2 is plain; enumerates specific grounds, cannot add others.

arguments.claim: Sub-section 3 makes certain conditions of the policy of no effect as against the 3rd party. Both Sub-ss. 2 and 3 are concerned only with the conditions of the policy.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  3  makes certain conditions of the policy of no effect as against the 3rd party. Both Sub-ss.  2  and  3  are concerned only with the conditions of the policy. They should not be interpreted so as to oust other defences the insurer may wish to take e.g. that there was no accident or that the plaintiff was negligent or that there was contributory negligence etc.

arguments.claim: The Court should interpret the section to give effect to the interests of justice.

anchor.surface_text: The Court should interpret the section to give effect to the interests of justice. The insurer is made liable to satisfy the judgment. It would be an extreme hardship if he were not allowed to defend the action on merits.

arguments.court_reasoning: No hardship; insurer can defend in name of assured, recover from insured.

arguments.claim: Apart from the situations coming within sub-s. 2 the insurer would be condemned unheard. The legislature could not have intended such a result.

anchor.surface_text: What s. 96 does is to roll up into one these three actions which occurred in English Law. But s. 96 does not give any party greater rights than it would have had in English Law.

holdings.text: Apart from the statute an insurer has no right to be made a party to the action by the injured person against the insured causing the injury.

anchor.surface_text: To start with it is necessary to remember that apart from the statute an insurer has no right to be made a party to the action by the injured person against the insured causing the injury.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Right to defend created solely by statute s.96(2); no common law or CPC basis apart from it.

holdings.text: An insurer added as defendant under s.96(2) is entitled to defend the action only on the grounds enumerated in that subsection and no others.

anchor.surface_text: Now the language of sub-s.  2  seems to us to be perfectly plain and to admit of no doubt or confusion. It is that an insurer to whom the requisite notice of the action has been given shall be entitled to be made a party thereto and to defend the action on any of the following grounds, namely,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.96(2) enumerates specific grounds; adding others would alter statutory words.

holdings.text: Sub-s.6 of s.96 prohibits insurer from avoiding liability except by the defences specified in sub-s.2.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 6 also indicates clearly how sub-s.  2 should be read. It says that no insurer to whom the notice of the action has been given shall be entitled to avoid his liability under sub-s.  1 otherwise than in the manner provided for in sub-section  2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Manner' in sub-s.6 refers to both procedure of joining and specific defences in sub-s.2; harmonious construction.

holdings.text: Sub-s.2 clearly provides that an insurer made a defendant to the action is not entitled to take any defence which is not specified in it.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore think that sub-s.  2  clearly provides that an insurer made a defendant to the action is number entitled to take any defence which is number specified in it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative reading of sub-ss.1,2,6; enumeration implies exclusivity; precedents align.

holdings.text: No addition of words to statute unless meaningless or ambiguous; language of sub-s.2 plain.

anchor.surface_text: The addition suggested will, in our view, make the language used unhappy and further effect a complete change in the meaning of the words used in the sub-section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules of interpretation prohibit inserting 'also' or similar; plain meaning governs.

holdings.text: Sub-s.2 deals with defences beyond mere policy conditions, including cancellation and non-disclosure.

anchor.surface_text: Sub- section  2  in fact deals with defences other than those based on the conditions of a policy. Thus cl.  a  of that sub-section permits an insurer to defend an action on the ground that the policy has been duly cancelled

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses (a),(c) cover non-condition defences; rejects claim limited to conditions.

holdings.text: No hardship to insurer; can defend in name of assured if reserved in policy, recover excess from insured.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory protections via policy clauses, recovery under sub-ss.3 proviso,4; business risk allocation equitable.

holdings.text: Loss should fall on insurer rather than innocent third party.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Purpose of compulsory insurance protects injured; insurer's business anticipates such risks.

anchor.surface_text: To start with it is necessary to remember that apart from the statute an insurer has no right to be made a party to the action by the injured person against the insured causing the injury.

We therefore think that sub-s. 2 clearly provides that an insurer made a defendant to the action is number entitled to take any defence which is number specified in it. Three reported decisions were cited at the bar and all of them proceeded on the basis that an insurer had numberright to defend the action except on the grounds mentioned in sub-s.  2 .

anchor.surface_text: Now the language of sub-s.  2  seems to us to be perfectly plain and to admit of no doubt or confusion. It is that an insurer to whom the requisite notice of the action has been given shall be entitled to be made a party thereto and to defend the action on any of the following grounds, namely,

We therefore think that sub-s. 2 clearly provides that an insurer made a defendant to the action is number entitled to take any defence which is number specified in it. Three reported decisions were cited at the bar and all of them proceeded on the basis that an insurer had numberright to defend the action except on the grounds mentioned in sub-s.  2 .

edges.explanation: Holding h3 prohibiting avoidance except by specified defences addresses issue i4 limiting available defences.
Holding h3 specifying 'defences' implies manner includes grounds, addressing issue i5.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 6 also indicates clearly how sub-s.  2 should be read. It says that no insurer to whom the notice of the action has been given shall be entitled to avoid his liability under sub-s.  1 otherwise than in the manner provided for in sub-section  2 .

We therefore think that sub-s. 2 clearly provides that an insurer made a defendant to the action is number entitled to take any defence which is number specified in it. Three reported decisions were cited at the bar and all of them proceeded on the basis that an insurer had numberright to defend the action except on the grounds mentioned in sub-s.  2 .
We therefore think that sub-s.  2  clearly provides that an insurer made a defendant to the action is number entitled to take any defence which is number specified in it.
